docs.title: Boot into the Live Environment
docs.text:
• Insert the NCOS installation media (USB or ISO).
  • Boot from the installation media.
  • The live environment will load, and the installer will launch automatically.

docs.title: Select Region, Timezone, and System Language
docs.text:
• Choose your preferred region and timezone.
  • Select the system language for your installation.

docs.title: Configure Keyboard Layout
docs.text:
• Pick your keyboard layout from the available options.
  • Test the layout to ensure it's correct.

docs.title: Partition the Drive
docs.text:
Choose the target drive for installation then select one of the partitioning methods:

  1. Install alongside existing OS – Keeps current partitions and installs NCOS alongside.
  2. Replace a partition – Overwrites an existing partition with NCOS.
  3. Erase disk – Deletes all partitions and installs NCOS on a clean disk.
  4. Manual partitioning – Allows advanced users to create custom partitions.

docs.title: Create a User
docs.text:
• Enter a username and password for your account.
  • Optionally, enable automatic login or require a password at startup.

docs.title: Begin Installation
docs.text:
• Review your settings.
  • Click Install to begin the process.
  • Wait for the installation to complete, then reboot into your new NCOS system.

docs.title: Pre-Installation Guide
docs.text: Before installing NCOS, follow these steps to prepare your system:

docs.title: Download the NCOS ISO
docs.text:
• Visit the NCOS official website for the download link.
  • Download the latest NCOS ISO file.

docs.title: Flash the ISO to a USB Drive
docs.text:
You need to create a bootable USB drive using the NCOS ISO. Here are two recommended tools:

WindowsLinux
  • Download and install Rufus on your Windows PC.
  • Open Rufus.
  • Select your USB drive from the "Device" dropdown menu.
  • Click "Select" and choose the NCOS ISO file.
  • Ensure the "Partition scheme" is set to GPT.
  • Leave the file system settings as default (usually FAT32).
  • Click "Start" to begin creating the bootable USB.
  • Once complete, safely eject the USB drive.
  • Download and install Etcher on your system.
  • Open Etcher.
  • Click "Flash from file" and select the NCOS ISO file.
  • Insert your USB drive, and Etcher will automatically detect it.
  • Click "Flash" to begin writing the ISO to the USB drive.
  • Wait for the process to complete.
  • Safely remove the USB drive from your system.

docs.title: Configure Your BIOS and Boot from USB
docs.text:
To boot into the NCOS live environment, follow these steps:

  1. Access the BIOS/UEFI:

    • Restart your computer and enter the BIOS/UEFI settings. The key to access the BIOS varies by manufacturer (e.g., F2, F10, Del, or Esc). Consult your system's manual for details.

  2. Disable Secure Boot:

    • Locate the Secure Boot option in your BIOS settings.
    • Disable Secure Boot to allow booting from the NCOS USB.

  3. Set USB as Boot Priority:

    • Navigate to the Boot Menu in your BIOS.
    • Set the USB drive as the first boot device.

  4. Save and Exit:

    • Save your changes and exit the BIOS.

docs.title: Step 4: Enter the Live Environment
docs.text:
• Insert your bootable USB drive into the target machine.
  • Restart the system. It should boot directly into the NCOS live environment.
  • If it doesn't boot, ensure that the USB is set as the first boot device in the BIOS settings.

docs.title: You're now ready to proceed with the Installation Process!
Get Started
docs.text:
Whether you're a new user or a seasoned developer, this documentation will guide you through every aspect of NCOS. Here's what you can find:

  • Installation Guide: Step-by-step instructions to install NCOS.
  • Getting Started: Learn the basics

docs.title: Add NCOS Repository
docs.text: Follow these steps to add the NCOS repository to your system and access NCOS-specific packages.

docs.title: Steps to Add the NCOS Repository
docs.text:
1.Open pacman.conf file:

Use the following command to open the pacman.conf file in any text editor:

sudo nano /etc/pacman.conf
2. Add NCOS repository configuration:

Append the following text to the end of the file:

[ncos]
SigLevel = Optional TrustAll
Server = https://raw.githubusercontent.com/exothermic88/ncos-repo/main/$arch
3. Synchronize NCOS repository:

Run the following command to add the NCOS repository to pacman (1):

  1. To learn more about pacman for package maintanance, refer to the arch wiki.

sudo pacman -Syy
4. Install NCOS-specific package:

Use the following command to install a NCOS package:

sudo pacman -S ncos-package_name

Example

sudo pacman -S ncos-hotfix

  1. Apply the update:

Run this command to apply the update:

ncos-package_name

Example

ncos-hotfix

docs.title: Future Updates
docs.text:
When future updates are released for ncos packages that you have already installed, they will be automatically downloaded when you update your system packages using sudo pacman -Syu.

  • To apply the updates, simply run the following command:
ncos-package_name

Instructions to Apply Brave Update

  1. Load the Extension

    • Open brave://extensions/.

docs.title: Maintaining NCOS ensures a smooth and efficient system. Follow these Directions to keep your system up to date and running optimally.
Keeping the System Updated
docs.text:
Recommended

To update all packages: 

sudo pacman -Syu
To update AUR packages only: 
yay --aur

For a full system upgrade including AUR packages : 

yay

docs.title: Removing Unused Packages
docs.text:
To remove orphaned packages: 

sudo pacman -Rns $(pacman -Qdtq)

Warning

Always double check the package list before deleting

docs.title: Clearing the Package Cache
docs.text:
To free up disk space: 

sudo pacman -Sc  # Remove old package versions
sudo pacman -Scc # Remove all cached packages

docs.title: Managing Services
docs.text:
Check the status of a service: 

systemctl status <service-name>
Enable a service at startup: 
sudo systemctl enable <service-name>
Disable a service: 
sudo systemctl disable <service-name>
Restart a service: 
sudo systemctl restart <service-name>

docs.title: Checking System Logs
docs.text:
View logs for troubleshooting: 

journalctl -xe
View logs for a specific service: 
journalctl -u <service-name> --no-pager

docs.title: Monitoring System Resources
docs.text:
To check system resource usage: 

htop
To check disk usage: 
df -h
